message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: A causal test of the strength of weak ties
Paper Abstract: The authors analyzed data from multiple large-scale randomized experiments on LinkedIn’s People You May Know algorithm, which recommends new connections to LinkedIn members, to test the extent to which weak ties increased job mobility in the world’s largest professional social network. The experiments randomly varied the prevalence of weak ties in the networks of over 20 million people over a 5-year period, during which 2 billion new ties and 600,000 new jobs were created. The results provided experimental causal evidence supporting the strength of weak ties and suggested three revisions to the theory. First, the strength of weak ties was nonlinear. Statistical analysis found an inverted U-shaped relationship between tie strength and job transmission such that weaker ties increased job transmission but only to a point, after which there were diminishing marginal returns to tie weakness. Second, weak ties measured by interaction intensity and the number of mutual connections displayed varying effects. Moderately weak ties (measured by mutual connections) and the weakest ties (measured by interaction intensity) created the most job mobility. Third, the strength of weak ties varied by industry. Whereas weak ties increased job mobility in more digital industries, strong ties increased job mobility in less digital industries.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of weak ties:

## Definition

Weak ties are acquaintanceships that are not reinforced by many mutual friendships, and they are also referred to as "peripheral" or "weak" ties. The "strength" of an interpersonal tie is a linear combination of the amount of time, the emotional intensity, the intimacy (or mutual confiding), and the reciprocal services which characterize each tie.

## Key Significance

Weak social ties are responsible for the majority of the embeddedness and structure of social networks in society as well as the transmission of information through these networks. More novel information flows to individuals through weak rather than strong ties.

## The Seminal Research

In 1973, Mark Granovetter published The Strength of Weak Ties, which is now recognized as one of the most influential sociology papers ever written. Granovetter found that most jobs were found through "weak" acquaintances. Granovetter's paper is one of the most influential articles in social science, with more than 78,000 citations according to Google Scholar (As of November 2025).

## Practical Applications

In marketing, information science, or politics, weak ties enable reaching populations and audiences that are not accessible via strong ties. Additionally, weak ties are positively related to higher wages and higher aggregate employment rates.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

In marketing, information science, or politics, weak ties enable reaching populations and audiences that are not accessible via strong ties. Additionally, weak ties are positively related to higher wages and higher aggregate employment rates.

Based on the search results, here's what you need to know about LinkedIn as a professional network:

## Overview

LinkedIn is an American business and employment-oriented social networking service.(no content)The platform is primarily used for professional networking and career development, as it allows jobseekers to post their CVs and employers to post their job listings.

## Key Features

The basic functionality of LinkedIn allows users to create profiles, which for employees typically consist of a curriculum vitae describing their work experience, education and training, skills, and a personal photo.(no content)Employers can list jobs and search for potential candidates, while users can find jobs, people and business opportunities recommended by someone in one's contact network.(no content)The site enables members to make "connections" to each other in an online social network which may represent real-world professional relationships, and users can obtain introductions to the connections of connections (termed second-degree connections) and connections of second-degree connections (termed third-degree connections).

## Ownership

In June 2016, Microsoft announced that it would acquire LinkedIn for $196 a share, a total value of $26.2 billion, and the deal was completed on December 8, 2016.

LinkedIn remains a dominant platform in professional networking, used by millions of professionals worldwide for career development, job searching, and business networking.

I've completed the web search for "job mobility labor market." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Labor or worker mobility is the geographical and occupational movement of workers.

## Benefits of Labor Mobility

Labor mobility theoretically leads to a more balanced and economically efficient distribution of jobs and resources overall, and individual employees can better match their skills to potential jobs on the open job market.

## Factors Affecting Mobility

Several factors influence whether workers move for jobs:

- **Education and Demographics**: Research shows that one's level of education tends to correlate to higher mobility, especially among university graduates, and youth and a lack of a family or children correlate to increased mobility.

- **Personal Considerations**: Personal preference factors besides economic logic can exert a strong influence on an individual's geographic mobility, with concerns such as climate, the strength of regional housing markets, cultural comfort, family, and local social capital all playing a role in the decision to move or not.

- **Barriers**: Impediments to mobility are easily divided into two distinct classes with one being personal and the other being systemic, with personal impediments including physical location, and physical and mental ability.

## Broader Impacts

Mobility can have negative consequences on a region facing widespread emigration, as brain drain and labor resource diminishment make it more difficult for troubled regions to recover after an economic stumble.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social networks:

## Definition

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Online Social Networking Services

A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections. More specifically, social networking sites are websites that facilitate the building of a network of contacts in order to exchange various types of content online.

## History and Development

Early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), with many of these early communities focusing on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms.(no content)In the early 2000s, social media platforms gained widespread popularity with BlackPlanet (1999) preceding Friendster and Myspace, followed by Facebook, YouTube, and Twitter.

## Current Usage and Growth

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media, some 59% of the global population.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

## Overview

Causal inference is the process of determining the independent, actual effect of a particular phenomenon that is a component of a larger system. The main difference between causal inference and inference of association is that causal inference analyzes the response of an effect variable when a cause of the effect variable is changed.

## Role of Randomized Experiments

In applied economics and political science, randomized field experiments are widely used to identify causal effects, since they help address confounding that complicates observational studies.(no content)Many economists have found RCTs are the gold standard for ensuring outcomes represent causal inference and not just correlation.

## How Randomization Eliminates Confounding

Randomization is the cornerstone of many scientific claims. To randomize means that we can eliminate the confounding factors. More specifically, random assignment plays a crucial role in the inference to causation because, in the long run, it renders the two groups equivalent in terms of all other possible effects on the outcome so that any changes in the outcome will reflect only the manipulation.

## Key Frameworks

The Rubin causal model (RCM), also known as the Neyman–Rubin causal model, is an approach to the statistical analysis of cause and effect based on the framework of potential outcomes. The potential outcomes framework was first proposed by Jerzy Neyman in his 1923 Master's thesis, though he discussed it only in the context of completely randomized experiments. Rubin extended it into a general framework for thinking about causation in both observational and experimental studies.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "A causal test of the strength of weak ties". Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Contribution

The paper is classified as a contribution because it reports results from original large-scale randomized experiments and proposes revisions to existing social network theory.

**Triples Identified:** 8 key concepts and methods

The analysis identified the following relationships:

**Uses (7 triples):**
1. **Randomized experiment** (method) - The experimental design methodology
2. **Causal inference** (concept) - The analytical approach for establishing causality
3. **LinkedIn** (tool) - The platform where experiments were conducted
4. **Interpersonal ties** (concept) - The core concept being tested (weak ties theory)
5. **Labor mobility** (task) - The primary outcome variable measured
6. **Social network** (concept) - The fundamental context of analysis
7. **Social network analysis** (method) - Techniques for measuring tie strength

**Proposes (1 triple):**
1. **Nonlinear relationship** (concept) - A novel inverted U-shaped relationship between tie strength and job transmission

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Interpersonal ties](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interpersonal_ties)
- [Labor mobility](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Labor_mobility)
- [Social network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network)
- [Causal inference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Causal_inference)
- [Randomized experiment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_experiment)
- [LinkedIn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LinkedIn)
- [Social network analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis)
